mentions.context: Oh, I was born in a little town of Remsen, Iowa, about 20 miles out of Sioux City, Iowa, in what was known as the Corn Belt of Iowa.
all the way up from Remsen, Iowa, up to Sioux Falls, Sioux City,
They moved away from Worthington, where we had started, and one day the boss come along and said, we're moving across the state, down near Sioux City, Iowa.
just south of Sioux City, Iowa, where we were working.
Whatever possessed my dad to leave that rich farmland down around Sioux City, Iowa, and move up into the frozen, rocky prairies, I will never know. However,
he said, "We're moving out of here, we're moving across the state to Sioux City, to south of Sioux City, Iowa.
So we moved across to a town by the name of Winnebago, Nebraska, just south of Sioux City, Iowa.
Well, we finished there and then I headed north I didn't know where I was going I stopped in at my brother's place in Sioux Falls and I had an uncle up near Aberdeen South Dakota so I
driving back to South Dakota, down to where my uncle lived at Frederick, out of Aberdeen, South Dakota.

After I finished there, I got in the car and I went up through by Lorry's place again, stopped there a couple of days, and then on up to Aberdeen, South Dakota, where I had an uncle and a cousin that - Irvine, the oldest boy was just my age.
near Aberdeen, South Dakota.
Then when I started work the next time, I was up near Aberdeen, South Dakota.
And a couple of weeks later, he still wasn't feeling well, so he went to Kenmare, North Dakota, where there were some renowned doctors.
When I got to Kenmare about two o'clock in the morning, well, I phoned the hospital and they said he was resting fine.
So I go up to Kenmare and I go into the office and tell him that I'd been talking to Leo O'Grady, a foreman.
And so he didn't feel any better, so he got on the train one day and went down to Kenmare, North Dakota.
And we went to ... that night and caught the train and got into Kenmare at about 2 o'clock in the morning after a big layover at that - Portal, at the international border...
Do you want ... the head office in Kenmare and see if they'll hire you?
And I worked with that outfit all winter, working up along the - from Kenmare, North Dakota, up to -
Kenmare, North Dakota, that was a year later.
all the way up from Remsen, Iowa, up to Sioux Falls, Sioux City,
And then one Sunday, I took a notion to drive up to see my brother Lorry up at Sioux Falls, South Dakota, which is about 150 miles away.
So I went back up to Sioux Falls and
...there and then I headed north I didn't know where I was going I stopped in at my brother's place in Sioux Falls and I had an uncle up near Aberdeen South Dakota so I
And I think I told you earlier in the story, when I quit in Nebraska and went up to work for my brother Lorry, who was sick at Sioux Falls, South Dakota.
...er in the story, when I quit in Nebraska and went up to work for my brother, Lorry, who was sick at Sioux Falls, South Dakota.
The first that I noticed of the depression was in the fall of 30, we were working in Biggar.
We finished the job at Estevan and then moved up to - down near the Assiniboia area and did some work, then up to Craik and Davidson, worked there for a while, and then up to Biggar.
Now, Biggar is a town about 3,000.
...ke his leg in the spring, was ready to come back to work, and Doboy's superintendent had come up to Biggar.
when I got that finished, he took me up to Biggar, Saskatchewan.
possibly spent a month in Davidson, and then on up to Biggar, east of Saskatoon, where we were doing a complete rebuild of the distribution system in a town of...
And I might relate that on the 4th day of October, we had a snowstorm that was so severe, and Biggar is on the main line of the CNR, all the trains were tied up.
In the town of Biggar itself, the only thing that could move up and down the streets was a team of horses on a gray wagon...
We bought a Williams boring machine from Billings, Montana, and it would only go down 18 feet.
We got the trouble book with it when we bought it from Billings, and the guy from the factory had been up there half a dozen times, couldn't figure why they were throwing clutches all the time.
I'd tell about buying the machine down at Billings, Montana.
While it was in Billings, they had a correspondence with the factory on it.
and somewhere past Crosby, about 30 miles, was the end of our last territory.
And everything was going fine until while we were working in Crosby, North Dakota, and one night they pound at the door and it was the immigration -
We had 150 miles of line from Mohall, North Dakota, over into the last town going out of North Dakota on the other side, Mohall -
Mohall was on the east
From there we moved over into Dawson, North Dakota.
And in Dawson, North Dakota, we were there building lines.
They went out from there, we went to Frederick, and then we moved up at - to Dawson, North Dakota, towards Spring.
driving back to South Dakota, down to where my uncle lived at Frederick, out of Aberdeen, South Dakota.
Well, when we got from Leola, we went up to Frederick, and I was acquainted with Frederick, and he knew that, so he used to keep me in about every second...
So I leave the outfit, and I go up back to Frederick to -
And when I got down there, well, I found out there's a power outfit working about 30 miles from there, and they were building a line into Frederick, South Dakota, what was where my uncle lived.
They went out from there, we went to Frederick, and then we moved up at - to Dawson, North Dakota, towards Spring.
...b just about finished when harvest time came, and I had a telegraph from Twight, the thrasher up in Frederick, to come back and run the separator,
I headed back up to Frederick.
I'll go back when I finish thrashing in Frederick and then headed north.
Oh, I was born in a little town of Remsen, Iowa, about 20 miles out of Sioux City, Iowa, in what was known as the Corn Belt of Iowa.
and go back and start relating the story from where I was born at Remsen, Iowa, October the 7th, 1902.
all the way up from Remsen, Iowa, up to Sioux Falls, Sioux City,
Well, I went into Valley City, and I patched it up enough that I could drive another hundred miles down to my uncle's place.
But I was able to drive it into Valley City, North Dakota, and there I tied it together.
While he was there, he found out there was a little town, Winnipegosis Manitoba that needed a power plant.
And they were moving that plant up to Winnipegosis.
So then I come back up to Winnipegosis, and I wound up there on Armistice Day.
And they were going to put the power plant up to Winnipegosis, Manitoba.
And then I went up, they said, "We're putting the plant up to Winnipegosis, Manitoba, and we want you to go up there and wire up the town.
They shipped their stuff back to Estevan, and Mac came up to Winnipegosis, Manitoba with me where we wired houses there.
This same man Dyer, when he left Tompkins, he went up to Winnipegosis and organized the starting of a power plant in Winnipegosis.
So we'll go on taping again about Winnipegosis.
So while I was wiring up at Winnipegosis, this fella took holidays, and they sent me down to Estevan for one month to take charge of the dis...
Thunder Hawk, South Dakota, up to Elgin, North Dakota, about 40 miles across.
Thunder Hawk, South Dakota, up to Algin North, right through No Man's Land.
running from Canora, Saskatchewan, up to Preeceville, and over to Norquay.
So I went to Canora and started that job, again without any help.
And then I - when I left the Canora job, left Jack Gardner in charge.
Yeah, after we finished up that line, then I got a job 30 miles from Yorkton to Canora.
They moved away from Worthington, where we had started, and one day the boss come along and said, we're moving across the state, down near Sioux City, Iowa.
So with that, I threw in the towel, and I packed up my suitcase, and a cousin from Worthington, Iowa, by the name of Norbert Hemmer, was up harvesting with us.
And I jumped in the car - in the car with him, and we drove straight through to Worthington, Iowa, which is about 1,300 miles.
So, anyway, I stayed with an uncle in Worthington, Iowa.
Well, I stayed in Worthington during December, doing nothing, just hanging around.
Worthington was about 300 people.
Worthington or working out of Worthington.
We were moving around the country, not necessarily always in Worthington.
When I started working in Worthington, Iowa, we were working nine hours a day, and I got 35 cents an hour, paid my own room and board, dr...
That takes in Lakeview, Albert Park, Whitmore Park,
I did a job from Vanguard to Aneroid, rebuilt a substation in there.
Did a bunch of Mennonite settlements there, and then down and put a line from Vanguard to Aneroid.
I was out west between Shaunavon and Assiniboia in 1935 and 1936, and there it was terrible.
And we were overhauling the power line that runs from Shaunavon to Assiniboia.
We finished the job at Estevan and then moved up to - down near the Assiniboia area and did some work, then up to Craik and Davidson, worked there for a while, and then up to Biggar.
I overhauled the power line from Shaunavon to Assiniboia for 120 miles.
...the next thing, George Jenney, he had saved his money, and he bought a section of land south of the Assiniboia.
I fired a guy down near Assiniboia.
However, I had a pretty well organized crew and we spent that summer - we had gone out through Assiniboia, did a little work onto Kincaid, and from there north up to Davidson.
And I went out and worked for them on the - overhauled the power line between Shaunavon and Assiniboia.
down at Ogema and Assiniboia countries, bit off more than he can chew, and I want you to go down there and help him out."

And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogemaâ€“Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
It was in the Sha - Ogema, Bengough,
We finished the job at Estevan and then moved up to - down near the Assiniboia area and did some work, then up to Craik and Davidson, worked there for a while, and then up to Biggar.
Then the old Dominion Electric had some work to do at Craik and Davidson, so I went down there and I worked there until the spring break up.
Oh yeah, in the meantime, this fellow that I took the plant over from had gone up to Dauphin, Manitoba.
In the meantime, I'd been - while I was in Iowa, my cousin from Nebraska, David City, Nebraska, said, when you're down in our part of the country, come and see us.
around Eastend for mule deer.
I was in Eastend.
When I finished that, I went down to the town of Eastend, which had another small decent plot, and down by Shaunavon.
But while I was there, I lined up a lot of wiring jobs, so I wired for three months - for a month in Eastend.
From there down to Shaunavon to Eastend, that was 30 miles.
She's keeping fine up in Edmonton.
I'm afraid Hamilton will have trouble with Edmonton.
He got on the phone and phoned Edmonton and got the repairs and put it in, and we never did have clutch trouble after that.

...up and found out there's room enough to double the capacity of the clutch. Got on the phone, phoned Edmonton, got the unnecessary parts, and took it to a machine shop, had a few alterations made and
Harold and Al died long ago, and Jack Bell has moved up to Edmonton.
And then I got an outfit from Edmonton to come down and -
Thunder Hawk, South Dakota, up to Elgin, North Dakota, about 40 miles across.
They were up at Elrose, hooking up a town, and they had trouble.
...ust north of Weyburn, and from there I got a job building a line from Dinsmore to Eston and up from Elrose to Rosetown.
And back to the job up at Elrose.
Rosetown - Elrose pretty well underway, and Art Miller was able to take over it.
So finally, I went over to Dins - to Rosetown - Elrose, and stayed on that job to push the wire stringing.
Oh, yes, the Elrose job, they didn't get it quite completed.
Up north from Kyle to Elrose, and we did about 50 farms up in there, plus 7 or 8 towns.

...ontana dakota power company in north dakota and then went to the dominion electric power company in estevan saskatchewan and the next electric company I worked for was the tompkins electric in saskatchewan w...
...ident of the Central Line Contractors Association, a charter member of the Kinsmen of Canada in the Estevan branch, a lifetime member of the BPOE Elks Lodge of Canada,
to Estevan and I don't know how far beyond.
or credit union in Estevan.
In the, you can say, Weyburn - Estevan area.
...started in Iowa, went to Nebraska, then South Dakota, then North Dakota, and finally I wound up at Estevan in 1929.
In 1930, when I started Estevan, I was making 82 cents an hour and paying my own keep.
And that winter they put me taking over service work in Estevan.
Then the power company in Estevan phoned me up one day and asked me to come down for about a month.
So I went down and I worked in Estevan for about a month.
Well, I could have bumped a married man in Estevan, but I said, "No way."
When I got back into Estevan again in 1937, all kinds of people were living off relief, right up until the war.
Like, again, I have to talk about Estevan and Bienfait, the coal mines where I knew every home.
Wherever you go, every small town, Waver and Estevan, the towns in between, all plugged full of used, good used cars, not junk cars, good used cars.
I drove into Estevan after they had the big strike, the coal miner strike down there and shot two or three guys.

When the harvest was finished, a buddy of mine and myself got in the car one Saturday, and we were going out for a little fun, and went down to Estevan, and the country was dry at that time, and so we landed in on the bootleggers, and having a drink in there when another friend of ours from our hometown came in and got talking. I asked what he's doing.
...had packed up my bag, which was the climbing tools and a few wrenches and a hammer, and I head for Estevan.
In the meantime, I head back to Estevan to see if I can get a job.
We finished the job at Estevan and then moved up to - down near the Assiniboia area and did some work, then up to Craik and Davids...
He said, "I want you to come back to Estevan and put Bill back in charge of the crew, and I want you to come back to Estevan.
But she said, "They've been trying to get a hold of you from Estevan."
So I worked in Estevan for about the month of October with the gang that was there.
He was a steam engineer from Estevan, and he was leaving them and going out to set up this small plant to get on his own.
So I phoned Estevan and told him about it and they were glad to get rid of him.
they needed me down at Estevan for a month.
I went down to Estevan for distribution, the mines and everything, for a month.
Well, when I went back to Estevan, I was back to Estevan by the end of, well, the middle of November.
Then I took over the distribution, operating, servicing all the mines and the town of Estevan.
Ohy, I got about two weeks on that and then come back to Estevan again.
And then I kept on working in Estevan until
And they were building an airport in Estevan, around '42, and ... one hell of a place to work.
So I pretty well had charge of everything in Estevan - distribution.
Then a little later, they bid on a line from Stoughton to Estevan.
I went to Estevan and really didn't do much of anything.
And then I went back to Estevan.
I was still living in Estevan at this time.
Went back to Estevan and started on my power line job, on my contract.
Oh, yeah, then we got the job building another chunk of the high-tension line from Estevan
I had one other fall when I was working for the power company in Estevan.
I think I told you I had $3,000 in the bank when I started, and I went to the bank manager in Estevan and told him I might need a little
...on overdraft. With the result that I never had to sign a note of any description. I operated out of Estevan
who started me up in Estevan, is the manager at Moose Jaw, and he'll take care of me."
...Yorkton and Art would do the job, and they're bidding on stringing a second circuit from Regina to Estevan.
A friend of mine and myself went on a little bit of a spree one Saturday afternoon and landed up in Estevan.
I headed to work in Estevan.
So we just tore up the contract we had signed, and I went back to work in Estevan.
He had come up from Estevan.
He said, "I thought you were back in Estevan working."
Well, I went back to Estevan.
...t word from the superintendent that Bill was coming to take over the crew and I was to come back to Estevan.
I went back to Estevan and I was more or less a one-man crew there by myself.
The roads were all bare from Estevan up here, and on the 21st day of January, if I recall correctly, I went to Saskatoon, and there was...
And in the fall, I went down to Estevan, and I went in to see the superintendent there.
One of their men was a fellow that I worked under, while I was in Estevan,
And then the spring of '34, Dubois, the superintendent, this was still the same company that was in Estevan, he said, "I'm putting you down in Gull Lake to do some wiring there.
So I phoned up Walter Stasher, the general manager in Estevan, and told him about this deal.
...ded in my car, so I didn't have a car, so they wrestled me up an old truck they had sitting down in Estevan.
...- my brother Mac, and Ellen, they broke up housekeeping there, and she went back to her parents in Estevan.
They shipped their stuff back to Estevan, and Mac came up to Winnipegosis, Manitoba with me where we wired houses there.
...d help him any, so I turned the whole issue over to the Dominion Electric, the old power company in Estevan.
...h yes, I was promised a job when they closed the plant down in Tompkins, that I would have a job at Estevan;
back at Estevan again.
So while I was wiring up at Winnipegosis, this fella took holidays, and they sent me down to Estevan for one month to take charge of the district there.
And I went back to Estevan and went to work.
And I worked in Estevan.
So I spent the war years in Estevan.
So I was pretty well in charge of everything at Estevan.
I won't promise you that you'll be back here in Estevan, but there'll be a job for you.
And at the same time bid on a big heavy, high voltage line from Estevan to Stoughton, and I get that too.
...tage suspension-type line, 72,000 volts, which was something new in Saskatchewan at that time, from Estevan to Stoughton, which was a distance of 40 miles.
First thing I did, I went to a dealer in Estevan, and he had a half-ton truck there.
And then I went back to Estevan and just sat in quiet until the spring, when the tenders come out.
And then I went back to Estevan and started building the
My old bank manager from Estevan, Bill Mullins, was the manager in Moose Jaw.
Along with that, the years in Estevan were really good educational years.
In my years in Estevan - when I left Estevan, I could have written steam papers.
I had 1200 customers in Estevan and I knew every one of them and they all knew me.

And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogemaâ€“Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
In the spring of '38, I went out and relieved out at Gravelbourg in Lafleche while they changed operators out there.
And in the fall of '38, I was sent out to Shaunavon and Gravelbourg to calibrate meters.
They were building another town out by Gull Lake.
Yeah, then in 34, then this same company said they'd put me into Gull Lake rewiring buildings, business places that were hay-wired in, you know, went and straightened up all...

stores in that town all winter. So I was busy making a living and that was about all. Then the next spring my old company Dominion Electric Dubois hired me to go into Gull Lake. There was some bad wiring jobs and they couldn't meter it properly in three or four places involving business places. So I went in and I straightened all that out. And
And then I come back to Gull Lake and I started overhauling the distribution system.

Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35...
...erintendent, this was still the same company that was in Estevan, he said, "I'm putting you down in Gull Lake to do some wiring there.
So I went into Gull Lake, and I -
And, uh, as I remember it, I finished and went back up to Gull Lake on Armistice Day.
Well, there wasn't much to do around Gull Lake, so there was some wiring to be done in Tompkins, and I moved back to Tompkins.
And then in '36, they decided they were going to run a power line from Gull Lake to Tompkins, and abandoned this little power plant.
Found out they could serve it cheaper in Gull Lake, and they had plenty of capacity there.
And, oh, yeah, the big city of Halbrite got on the news
But when he's at Halbrite about 5 o'clock in the morning,
and went about nine miles to north of Halbrite out into a field
I was at Halbrite.
I was brought up on a farm at Halbrite.
We're in a small community in Halbrite.
and then up what they call the Sioux Line, up to Halbrite.
However, we landed at Halbrite.
Six miles north of Halbrite.
And then she went to high school in Halbrite and got her grade nine.
Every other Sunday, we went to Mass in Halbrite.
So I phoned back up to Halbrite and talked to my Aunt Mary.
We had the body shipped back to Halbrite for burial, and
The way I go, I go down to Halbrite - Midale.
tearing down airport lines at Midale and Halbrite, all in through there, and building up into power lines in those small towns."

...using that same material or what was usable, build a power line - well in one case, from Macoun to Halbrite. And we were all bidding that close. It was almost impossible to think that four men could sit down...
I tore down the airports, and I got the line going from Halbrite to Midale,
We landed up at Halbrite the 17th day of March.
From there on, I got back to the hotel, and I phoned my aunt back at Halbrite to find out
First, I distinctly remember coming to Halbrite when I was four and a half years old.
Well, I'll head up towards Halbrite.
This funeral took place in Halbrite, and some of the big shots come up to the funeral.
And when they got to Halbrite, there was no place to eat, so they phoned out to the farm.
And when I got back to Halbrite - Midale, here Midale we're going to put in the power plant, and a power system.
And by God, I get - the first job I get is building a line from Halbrite to Midale and the distribution system in - yeah, and Macoun - and the distribution system in Macoun...
One was a power line from Midale to Halbrite and Macoun,
And then use all the usable material to build a power line, as I said, from Halbrite to Midale to Macoun.
So when we got over to, it was Homer, Nebraska,
And then they were putting in a power plant out of Hopkins, which was 18 miles from the nearest power plant, so they put in another isolated plant, a little diesel plant.
Oh, yes, we'd come back up and build a line from Montmartre to Kipling, which was about 50 or 60 miles, and built two or three towns along with that.
And then after that, came in and went from Montmartre to Kipling.
Well, we never got as far as the Manitoba border, about Kipling to the east, and everything - always south of the valley, south of the Saskatchewan River and the Q...
So while I was there, my cousin said, hey, there's a power gang working down here at Leola, about 25 miles from there.
Well, when we got from Leola, we went up to Frederick, and I was acquainted with Frederick, and he knew that, so he used to keep...
got my car patched up enough that I was able to drive down to - to this town, Leola was the name of the town, see if I can get a job on this power line.

...Alberta about the end of harvest and we worked up there. We did some highline move where they're building a high - it was up at the Vermillion and Lloydminster area, They were moving a highway - or widening a highway, and we moved some line for that. And then we put in a - a section of farm land - farm line there, about 50 miles of farm line.
in Lloydminster had one, asked him, "What do you do for clutch?"
Built in a bunch of farms up around Lloydminster and Vegreville.

and, tearing down all these old power lines, and there's telephones and power and everything mixed up. And then, using that same material or what was usable, build a power line - well in one case, from Macoun to Halbrite. And we were all bidding that close. It was almost impossible to think that four men could sit down individually and come up within a thousand dollars from top to bottom. Anyway,
and then part of it to Macoun.
...rst job I get is building a line from Halbrite to Midale and the distribution system in - yeah, and Macoun - and the distribution system in Macoun and Halbrite.
One was a power line from Midale to Halbrite and Macoun,
And then use all the usable material to build a power line, as I said, from Halbrite to Midale to Macoun.
And then when I come back, I get in the town of Midale, where my brother married a girl from Midale.
And there they want to put a little power system in Midale.
Oh, well, I was, yeah, in Midale.
I wired homes all winter in Midale in 19... Who was paying for the wiring?
Midale doctor was the one that would come out.
Well, the barber in Midale, he's still living.
The way I go, I go down to Halbrite - Midale.
Mac was living in Midale.
Brother, Mac was living in Midale.
Midale wanted to put in a power plant.
When I come back, I want to work in Iowa, or in Midale and put in the distribution system.
tearing down airport lines at Midale and Halbrite, all in through there, and building up into power lines in those small towns."
I tore down the airports, and I got the line going from Halbrite to Midale,
and I kept him going all winter in Midale.
And when I got back to Halbrite - Midale, here Midale we're going to put in the power plant, and a power system.
...d built the system, then my brother Mac and I started wiring houses, and we wired all the houses in Midale, which is a total winter job.
And then Mac and I, we "checked out", as I said, about the middle of November, and he went back to Midale.
And by God, I get - the first job I get is building a line from Halbrite to Midale and the distribution system in - yeah, and Macoun - and the distribution system in Macoun and Halbr...
One was a power line from Midale to Halbrite and Macoun,
So to get back to when I started out from Midale,
So I took those trucks and revamped them, took them down to Midale and,
And then use all the usable material to build a power line, as I said, from Halbrite to Midale to Macoun.
At the time I built the power system into the village of Midale.
And we would have had to stop possibly overnight in Minneapolis when we got there.
and I still remember us being in Minneapolis.
Then I remember going home from Minneapolis,
This train ride to Minneapolis home was about,
to Minneapolis, yes.
to get from our place up to Minneapolis.
And then mother stayed down in Iowa and Dad came home with me. And we stopped in Minneapolis, and I still remember him taking me to the bar room that night while he went in to have a drink,
I got up as far as Minot, North Dakota, and I stopped in the city there to see if I could get a job.
I got up as far as Minot.
When I got to Minot, I thought I'd look for a job - and I meant to check in here.
Oh, yes, we'd come back up and build a line from Montmartre to Kipling, which was about 50 or 60 miles, and built two or three towns along with that.
And then after that, came in and went from Montmartre to Kipling.

The potash out at Kalium between here and Moose Jaw start up and we did all their distribution layout for - not only did the engineering as well as building the lines. And uh that lasted for I guess it's still going today. That
And the first setback they had was when Vaughn Kennedy was electrocuted doing some work at the Moose Jaw Airport.
And I said, "If you don't, I'll move my account to Moose Jaw where my old friend Bill Mullins
who started me up in Estevan, is the manager at Moose Jaw, and he'll take care of me."
So, I went up to Moose Jaw and they held a writing in there, and it was the worst headache I ever had in my life. I went in th...
So I happened to be going through Moose Jaw.
My old bank manager from Estevan, Bill Mullins, was the manager in Moose Jaw.
Ron Kennedy, as you know got - was electrocuted at Moose Jaw.

And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogemaâ€“Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
down at Ogema and Assiniboia countries, bit off more than he can chew, and I want you to go down there and help h...
It was in the Sha - Ogema, Bengough,
And then in - to get back to the story again, by this time, Dominion Electric were getting pretty big up in the Peace River country.
So this night, Dubois phoned me from Peace River.
Oh yeah, the company had moved up into the Peace River country pretty strong by that time, and the superintendent spending a lot of time up there.
